name: Druidic Knowledge System
driver_note: Roman conquest banned Druids, Christianity finished suppression. Same pattern as other conquest + religious destruction.
what_lost: Astronomy, law, philosophy, medicine, religious practices, oral histories
quantity: Entire knowledge system of Celtic peoples
description: The Druids maintained an extensive oral tradition across the Celtic world — Britain, Gaul, Ireland. They deliberately refused to write, believing sacred knowledge should be memorized. Training took up to 20 years. Julius Caesar banned them in Gaul. Roman emperors outlawed them in Britain. Christianity suppressed the remnants. Unlike burned libraries, oral traditions leave no fragments. When the last trained Druids died, the knowledge died with them.
sources: The World of the Druids (Miranda Green, 1997)

name: Inca Quipus
driver_note: Spanish Catholic destruction of 'idolatrous' records. Same pattern as Aztec and Maya codex burnings.
what_lost: Historical records, census data, accounting, possibly narratives and literature
quantity: Thousands of quipus destroyed. ~600 survive, mostly undeciphered.
description: The Inca had no writing system but used quipus — knotted strings encoding information through colors, knot types, and positions. Spanish colonizers destroyed thousands as 'works of the devil.' The few who could read them died without passing on the knowledge. About 600 quipus survive in museums. We can decode simple numerical data but the full system — possibly including histories, songs, and laws — remains undeciphered. The key died with the quipucamayocs (quipu keepers).
sources: Signs of the Inka Khipu (Gary Urton, 2003)

name: Zoroastrian Texts (Avesta)
driver_note: Alexander burned Persepolis and its royal archives. Later Arab conquest destroyed more. Conquest pattern repeated.
what_lost: Religious texts, scientific treatises, royal archives, astronomical records
quantity: Original Avesta reportedly 21 volumes (nasks). Only ~25% survives.
description: The Zoroastrian scriptures (Avesta) were kept in the royal library at Persepolis. When Alexander burned the city in 330 BCE, much was destroyed. The remaining texts were further damaged during the Arab conquest of Persia (7th century CE). The original Avesta reportedly contained 21 nasks (volumes) covering cosmology, law, medicine, and astronomy. Only about a quarter survives. Zoroastrian priests preserved what they could through memorization, but the scientific and astronomical treatises were largely lost.

name: Library of Carthage
driver_note: Roman total war. City razed, population killed or enslaved. Same annihilation logic as conquest genocides.
what_lost: Punic literature, history, navigation, agriculture, Mago's treatises
description: When Rome destroyed Carthage in 146 BCE, they burned one of antiquity's great libraries. Carthage was a major Mediterranean power with advanced navigation and agriculture. Mago's 28-volume treatise on agriculture was so valued that the Roman Senate ordered it translated before the burning. Almost nothing else survived. The city was razed, the ground salted.

name: Library of Alexandria
driver_note: Christian mob destruction (391 CE). 'Pagan knowledge' targeted. Same purification logic as religious genocide.
description: The accumulated knowledge of the ancient world. Multiple destruction events: Caesar's fire (48 BCE), Christian destruction (391 CE), Arab conquest (642 CE). Lost works include most of Aristotle, most Greek dramatists, scientific treatises we only know by name.
sources: The Rise and Fall of the Library of Alexandria (Mostafa El-Abbadi, 1990)

name: Silphium Extinction
driver_note: Overexploitation for profit. Same extraction logic as profit-driven atrocities like Congo Free State.
description: The most valuable plant in the ancient Mediterranean. Worth its weight in silver. Overharvested to extinction by ~100 CE. For nearly 2,000 years after (until the 1960s), no reliable contraceptive existed. We don't know what species it was. We can't recreate it.

name: Nalanda University
driver_note: Turkic invaders targeted Buddhist institution. Monks killed, library burned. Religious conquest pattern.
what_lost: Buddhist philosophy, logic, mathematics, astronomy, medicine
quantity: Millions of manuscripts (9 million according to some sources)
description: The world's first residential university. Attracted scholars from across Asia for 700 years. Destroyed by Turkic invaders in 1193. The library reportedly burned for three months. Virtually forgotten until rediscovered in the 19th century. Monks who escaped carried fragments to Tibet, preserving some texts.
sources: Xuanzang's Great Tang Records on the Western Regions (7th century)

name: House of Wisdom (Baghdad)
driver_note: Mongol conquest. Knowledge destruction as total war. Same logic as conquest genocides.
what_lost: Islamic Golden Age science, mathematics, astronomy, medicine, philosophy
description: Destroyed by Mongols in 1258. The Tigris reportedly ran black with ink from books thrown in the river. 500 years of Islamic Golden Age scholarship lost. Mathematics, astronomy, medicine, philosophy.

name: Imperial Library of Constantinople
driver_note: Ottoman conquest. Last repository of Greco-Roman knowledge lost to territorial war.
description: Last major repository of Greco-Roman knowledge. Survived 1,000 years after Alexandria. Damaged by fire in 473 CE (120,000 documents lost), looted in Fourth Crusade (1204), final destruction when Ottomans conquered Constantinople in 1453. Some scholars fled to Italy, sparking the Renaissance. Most was lost.
sources: Byzantium: The Decline and Fall (John Julius Norwich, 1995)

name: Aztec Codices
driver_note: Spanish Catholic purge of 'pagan' texts. Same religious purification as Maya destruction.
what_lost: History, astronomy, tribute records, religious texts, poetry
description: Moctezuma's palace held extensive libraries of painted books. After the conquest of Tenochtitlan (1521), Spanish friars systematically destroyed codices as works of the devil. Of perhaps 500 pre-conquest codices, only 2-16 are considered genuine pre-Hispanic. The Florentine Codex (1540-1585) was compiled from elder memories of what was burned.
sources: Burning of the Books in the Aztec and Maya World (Hanns Prem, 2008)

name: Maya Codices (Maní)
driver_note: De Landa: 'superstition and lies of the devil'. Same purification logic as religious genocide.
description: Bishop Diego de Landa burned 5,000+ Maya books: 'We found a large number of books... and as they contained nothing but superstition and lies of the devil, we burned them all.' The 4 survivors contain sophisticated astronomical calculations. The Dresden Codex has Venus tables accurate to within 2 hours over 500 years.
sources: Relación de las cosas de Yucatán (Diego de Landa, 1566)

name: Tasmanian Languages
driver_note: Languages died with speakers during ethnic cleansing. Linguistic genocide as dimension of physical genocide.
what_lost: 8+ complete languages, 35,000 years of ecological knowledge
description: 8+ distinct languages. All extinct. Last fluent speaker (Fanny Cochrane Smith) died 1905. These contained names for plants and animals unknown to science, ecological knowledge accumulated over 35,000 years, oral histories we'll never hear. When the last speaker dies, the library burns.
sources: Extinction: A Very Short Introduction (Paul Wignall, 2019)

name: Institut für Sexualwissenschaft
driver_note: Nazi ideological purification. Same logic as racial genocide applied to 'degenerate' knowledge.
what_lost: Gender and sexuality research, medical records, patient files
description: Founded 1919 by Magnus Hirschfeld. Pioneering research on gender and sexuality. On May 6, 1933, Nazi students stormed the institute. On May 10, the contents were publicly burned. The famous photographs of Nazi book burnings are mostly of this library. Research set back decades. Patient records destroyed, endangering those documented.

name: Yiddish Libraries and Publishing
driver_note: Nazi genocide targeted Jewish culture alongside Jewish people. Language survived; libraries did not.
what_lost: Yiddish literature, manuscripts, newspapers, theater archives, religious texts
quantity: Millions of books, countless manuscripts. 11M speakers → language endangered.
description: Before the Holocaust, Yiddish was spoken by 11 million Jews across Europe. The genocide destroyed not just speakers but the entire cultural infrastructure: libraries, publishing houses, newspapers, theaters, schools. The language survived in Hasidic communities, but millions of books and unique manuscripts were burned. Less than 5% of published Yiddish books have been translated.
sources: YIVO Encyclopedia of Jews in Eastern Europe

name: National Library of Sarajevo
driver_note: Deliberate targeting during ethnic cleansing. Destroy shared history to divide peoples.
what_lost: Bosnian cultural heritage, records of coexistence
description: Deliberately targeted with incendiary shells (August 25-26, 1992). Firefighters who tried to save it were shot at by snipers. Unique records of Bosnian Muslim, Croat, and Serb coexistence. The destruction of shared history was part of ethnic cleansing.
sources: Killing Memory: The Targeting of Bosnia's Cultural Heritage (András Riedlmayer, 1994)
